Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Workshop on Meteorological Sensitivity Analysis and Data Assimilation; Aveiro, Portugal; July 2-6, 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for travel support for 5-6 researchers from the U.S. to participate in an international workshop titled: "Meteorological Sensitivity Analysis and Data Assimilation," to be held in Aveiro, Portugal from July 2-6, 2018. Presentations will include a mix of tutorials on fundamentals, overview talks on recent development paths, posters or short seminars on new findings, and some formal debates. Students will have an opportunity to present their work. The workshop will be held at a self-contained facility at which all participants will share meals and evening discussions, providing many opportunities for dialogue with and between experts to make maximum use of time.

Data assimilation lies at the heart of numerical weather prediction that, in turn, lies at the heart of weather forecasting. Much of the improved accuracy of weather forecasts during the past decade is due to improvements in the accuracy of estimates of the current weather that data assimilation provides. Implicit or explicit sensitivity analysis is a key component of both data assimilation and weather forecasting, since it links uncertainties of predictions with uncertainties of initial condition or observations. Both data assimilation and sensitivity analysis are computationally intensive, complex, multidisciplinary subjects. In order to expedite progress in these studies and their applications, it is necessary to establish proper foundations and to perform robust evaluations for all scientific claims. These are the primary aims of the workshop, with its principal societal impact being the further improvement of weather analysis and forecasting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop on Sensitivity Analysis and Data Assimilation in Meteorology was a sequel to the Tenth Workshop on Applications of Adjoint Models in Dynamic Meteorology.  This series of open meetings have been designed to facilitate scientific exchange and teaching about methods and applications of sensitivity analysis and data assimilation, whether or not  adjoint models are used and not only in meteorology but also in other scientific or engineering fields. All the workshops are convened at self-contained conference centers in rural areas where participants are given ample time to converse over meals and evening socials.  The formats are designed for encouraging questioning as well as extended discussion, and always include tutorials on fundamental topics. Speakers are specifically asked to teach others something about what they have learned from their research rather than to primarily advertise what they have done.  The topics addressed are determined by soliciting the research community.

This latest workshop was convened 1-6 July 2018 at the Melia Ria Hotel in Aveiro, Portugal. There were 81 participants, including 20 women, with 37 participants from the United States.  The quality of the presentations and venue were excellent.  The workshop was supported by the U.S. National Science Foundation and the U. K. Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council.  Partial travel expenses for 9 students from the U.S. were provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation through Morgan state University, Baltimore, for a total of $10,000. An additional 6 students from Europe, Asia, and South America were supported the U. K. Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council through the University of Reading, England, for an additional $5000.

The workshop program, abstracts and presentations can be found at https://www.morgan.edu/adjoint_workshop
